dialogs.original: Where the devil should this Romeo be?Came he not home tonight?
dialogs.translated: Where the devil is Romeo? Did he come home last night?

dialogs.original: Not to his fathers. I spoke with his man.
dialogs.translated: Not to his fathers house. I asked Romeos servant.

dialogs.original: Why, that same pale hard-hearted wench, that Rosaline, Torments him so, that he will sure run mad.
dialogs.translated: Rosalinethat pale-skinned, hard-hearted wenchtorments him so much that hes going to go insane.

dialogs.original: Tybalt, the kinsman to old Capulet,Hath sent a letter to his fathers house.
dialogs.translated: Tybalt, old Capulets kinsman, has sent a letter to Romeos fathers house.

dialogs.original: A challenge, on my life.
dialogs.translated: I bet its a challenge to fight.

dialogs.original: Romeo will answer it.
dialogs.translated: Romeo will answer it.

dialogs.original: Any man that can write may answer a letter.
dialogs.translated: Any man who can write is able to answer a letter.

dialogs.original: Nay, he will answer the letters master, how he dares, being dared.
dialogs.translated: No, Romeo will respond to the letter writer and accept the challenge.

dialogs.original: Alas, poor Romeo! He is already dead, stabbed with a white wenchs black eye, shot through the ear with a love song,   the very pin of his heart cleft with the blind bow-boys butt shaft. And is he a man to encounterTybalt?
dialogs.translated: Poor Romeo! He is already dead: stabbed by the black eye of a fair-skinned girl, cut through the ear by a love song. The very core of his heart has been split by blind Cupids arrow. Is he really man enough to fight Tybalt?

dialogs.original: Why, what is Tybalt?
dialogs.translated: Why, whats up with Tybalt?

dialogs.original: More than Prince of Cats. Oh, hes the courageous captain of compliments. He fights as you sing prick-song, keeps time, distance, and proportion.   He rests his minim restsone, two, and the third in your bosom.   The very butcher of a silk button, a duelist, a duelist, a gentleman of the very first house of the first and second cause.   Ah, the immortal passado, the punto reverso, the hai!
dialogs.translated: Hes more than just the Prince of Cats. Oh, he does everything according to convention. He fights like you sing printed music, carefully keeping the correct time, distance, and rhythm. He rests when it is proper to rest: one, two, and the third in your heart. Hes a master duelist who can hit any of his opponents buttons that he chooses. Hes a gentleman who learned at the finest fencing school, and hes skilled at identifying insults and slights to his honor so that hes forced to fight. He knows the passadothe forward thrustthe punto reversothe backhand thrustand the haithe thrust for the heart.

dialogs.original: The what?
dialogs.translated: He knows what?

dialogs.original: The pox on such antic, lisping, affecting fantasmines, these new tuners of accents! By Jesu, a very good blade! A very tall man! A very good whore!   Why, is not this a lamentable thing, grandsire, that we should be thus afflicted with these strange flies, these fashion-mongers, these pardon mes,   who stand so much on the new form, that they cannot sit at ease on the oldbench? Oh, their bones, their bones!
dialogs.translated: A curse on these wild, pompous fellows who are always spouting exotic foreign phrases. These fellows, who say things like: By Jesus, this is a very good blade! A very brave man! A very good whore. Isnt it a sad thing, good man, that we are forced to interact with these foreign flies, these fashionmongers, these fellows who say pardon me and care so deeply about good manners that they cant relax on a bench without groaning, Oh, my aching bones!

dialogs.original: Here comes Romeo, here comes Romeo.
dialogs.translated: Here comes Romeo, here comes Romeo.

dialogs.original: Without his roe, like a dried herring. O flesh, flesh,how art thou fishified! Now is he for the numbers that Petrarch flowed in.   Laura to his lady was but a kitchen-wench marry, she had a better love to berhyme her   Dido a dowdy, Cleopatra a gypsy, Helen and Hero hildings and harlots, Thisbe a grey eye or so, but not to the purpose.    Signior Romeo, bonjour! Theres a French salutation to your French slop. You gave us the counterfeit fairly last night.
dialogs.translated: He looks skinny as a dried herring without its eggs. O flesh, flesh, youve turned pale as a fish. Now hes just like Petrarchs hopeless love poetry. In Romeos opinion, compared to his own lady love: Petrarchs Laura was like a kitchen slavethough Laura clearly had a lover who was better at making rhymes; Dido was drab and dull; Cleopatra was a gypsy girl; Helen and Hero were good-for-nothing harlots; Thisbe might have had beautiful eyes, but that doesnt matter.

dialogs.original: Good morrow to you both. What counterfeit did I give you?
dialogs.translated: Good morning to you both. What do you mean I tricked you?

dialogs.original: The slip, sir, the slip. Can you not conceive?
dialogs.translated: You gave us the slip, sir, the slip. Do you understand me now?

dialogs.original: Pardon, good Mercutio, my business was great, and in such a case as mine a man may strain courtesy.
dialogs.translated: Im sorry, good Mercutio. My business was so important that I must be forgiven for stretching good manners and courtesy.

dialogs.original: Thats as much as to say, such a case as yours constrains a man to bow in the hams.
dialogs.translated: So what youre saying is that your business forced you to flex your legs.

dialogs.original: Meaning to curtsy?
dialogs.translated: Meaning make a curtsy?

dialogs.original: Thou hast most kindly hit it.
dialogs.translated: Now youve hit it.

dialogs.original: A most courteous exposition.
dialogs.translated: What a courteous explanation.

dialogs.original: Nay, I am the very pink of courtesy.
dialogs.translated: Indeed, I am the very pink of courtesy.

dialogs.original: Pink for flower.
dialogs.translated: As in the pink flower.

dialogs.original: Right.
dialogs.translated: Right.

dialogs.original: Why, then is my pump well flowered.
dialogs.translated: Well, then my pump is covered in flowers.

dialogs.original: Sure wit, follow me this jest now till thou hast worn out thy pump, that when the single sole of it is worn, the jest may remain, after the wearing solely singular.
dialogs.translated: Ah, witty Romeo, now youve taken this joke so far that its worn out your pump. With the sole of your pump now worn away, the joke is all that remains.

dialogs.original: O single-soled jest, solely singular for the singleness.
dialogs.translated: This jest has such a thin sole, and is unique only because of its lameness.

dialogs.original: Come between us, good Benvolio. My wits faints.
dialogs.translated: Please break up this war of words, Benvolio. My wits cant keep up.

dialogs.original: Switch and spurs, switch and spurs, or Ill cry a match.
dialogs.translated: Continue, continue, or Ill proclaim victory.

dialogs.original: Nay, if our wits run the wild-goose chase, I am done, for thou hast more of the wild-goose in one of thy wits than, I am sure, I have in my whole five. Was I with youthere for the goose?
dialogs.translated: No, if our witticisms go on a wild-goose chase, Im done for. You have more wild goose in one of your jokes than I have in five of mine. Was I  even close to you in our goose chase?

dialogs.original: Thou wast never with me for anything when thou wast notthere for the goose.
dialogs.translated: You would not have been with me for anything if you werent there for the goose.

dialogs.original: I will bite thee by the ear for that jest.
dialogs.translated: Ill bite you on the ear for that joke.

dialogs.original: Nay, good goose, bite not.
dialogs.translated: No, good goose, dont bite me.

dialogs.original: Thy wit is a very bitter sweeting. It is a most sharp sauce.
dialogs.translated: Your wit is a bitter apple. It is a very spicy sauce.

dialogs.original: And is it not well served into a sweet goose?
dialogs.translated: Isnt that the perfect sauce for a sweet goose?

dialogs.original: Oh, heres a wit of cheveril, that stretches from an inch narrow to an ell broad!
dialogs.translated: Oh, that joke is made of leather so thin it has been stretched from an inch wide to a full fat yard.

dialogs.original: I stretch it out for that word broad, which, added to the goose, proves thee far and wide a broad goose.
dialogs.translated: I stretched it for that word fat. Add that to the goose, and it makes you a fat goose.

dialogs.original: Why, is not this better now than groaning for love? Nowart thou sociable. Now art thou Romeo.   Now art thou what thou artby art as well as by nature, for this driveling love is like a great natural that runs lollingup and down to hide his bauble in a hole.
dialogs.translated: Now, isnt this jesting better than groaning about love? Now youre being sociable. Now youre Romeo. Now you are what you truly are, both naturally and through education. In contrast, this love of yours made you like some fool who runs all over the place looking for a hole in which to hide his precious trinket.

dialogs.original: Stop there, stop there.
dialogs.translated: Stop there, stop there.

dialogs.original: Thou desirest me to stop in my tale against the hair.
dialogs.translated: Youre asking me to stop my tale before its finished.

dialogs.original: Thou wouldst else have made thy tale large.
dialogs.translated: Continuing on would have made your tale too long.

dialogs.original: Oh, thou art deceived. I would have made it short, forI was come to the whole depth of my tale, and meant, indeed, to occupy the argument no longer.
dialogs.translated: Youre wrong there. I would have made it short. I had come to the full depth of my tale, and intended to say nothing more about it.

dialogs.original: Heres goodly gear.
dialogs.translated: Now heres something.

dialogs.original: A sail, a sail!
dialogs.translated: A sail, a sail!

dialogs.original: Two, twoa shirt and a smock.
dialogs.translated: No, two sailsa man in a shirt and a woman in a dress.

dialogs.original: Peter!
dialogs.translated: Peter!

dialogs.original: Anon!
dialogs.translated: In a moment.

dialogs.original: My fan, Peter.
dialogs.translated: Give me my fan, Peter.

dialogs.original: Good, Peter, to hide her face, for her fans the fairerface.
dialogs.translated: Good Peter, to hide her face, please give her the fan. Her fan is prettier than her face.

dialogs.original: God ye good morrow, gentlemen.
dialogs.translated: Good morning, gentlemen.

dialogs.original: God ye good een, fair gentlewoman.
dialogs.translated: Good afternoon, beautiful lady.

dialogs.original: Is it good een?
dialogs.translated: Is it afternoon?

dialogs.original: Tis no less, I tell you, for the bawdy hand of the dial is now upon the prick of noon.
dialogs.translated: Its not any earlier, I tell you. The lusty hand of the clock is now upon the prick of noon.

dialogs.original: Out upon you! What a man are you?
dialogs.translated: Get out of town! What kind of man are you?

dialogs.original: One, gentlewoman, that God hath made, himself to mar.
dialogs.translated: A man, good lady, whom God has made for himself to ruin.

dialogs.original: By my troth, it is well said. For himself to mar, quoth he? Gentlemen, can any of you tell me where I may find the young Romeo?
dialogs.translated: I swear, that seems the truth. For himself to ruin, he says. Gentlemen, can any of you tell me where I can find young Romeo?

dialogs.original: I can tell you, but young Romeo will be older when you have found him than he was when you sought him. I am theyoungest of that name, for fault of a worse.
dialogs.translated: I can tell you, but young Romeo will be older when you have found him than he was when you began to look for him. I am the youngest man by that name, because there is none younger or worse.

dialogs.original: You say well.
dialogs.translated: You speak well.

dialogs.original: Yea, is the worst well? Very well took, i faith, wisely, wisely.
dialogs.translated: Is the worst well? Very well taken, in truth, very wise.

dialogs.original: If you be he, sir, I desire some confidence with you.
dialogs.translated: If youre Romeo, sir, I would like to have a private conversation with you.

dialogs.original: She will indite him to some supper.
dialogs.translated: She will invite him to dinner.

dialogs.original: A bawd, a bawd, a bawd! So ho!
dialogs.translated: A pimp! A pimp! A pimp! Thats it!

dialogs.original: What hast thou found?
dialogs.translated: What have you discovered?

dialogs.original: No hare, sir, unless a hare, sir, in a Lenten piethat is, something stale and hoar ere it be spent.    [Sings]     An old hare hoar,    And an old hare hoar,    Is very good meat in Lent.    But a hare that is hoar    Is too much for a score    When it hoars ere it be spent.     [He speaks]   Romeo, will you come to your fathers? Well to dinner, thither.
dialogs.translated: Well, she cant be a prostitute unless shes so stale and old that shes only tasted when nothing else is available.[He sings]Old rabbit meat Old rabbit meatIs good meat if you cant get anything else,But old moldy rabbit,Is a waste of your coinIf it goes moldy before you can eat it[He speaks] Romeo, are you going to your fathers? Were having lunch there. Lets go.

dialogs.original: I will follow you.
dialogs.translated: Ill follow after you.

dialogs.original: Farewell, ancient lady. Farewell, lady, lady, lady.
dialogs.translated: Farewell, old lady. Farewell, lady, lady, lady.

dialogs.original: I pray you, sir, what saucy merchant was this that was so full of his ropery?
dialogs.translated: Please tell me, sir, who was that foulmouthed fellow with all his dirty jokes?

dialogs.original: A gentleman, Nurse, that loves to hear himself talk, and will speak more in a minute than he will stand to ina month.
dialogs.translated: Nurse, hes a gentleman who loves to hear himself talk. He says more in one minute than he will stand behind in a month.

dialogs.original: An he speak any thing against me, Ill take him down, an he were lustier than he is, and twenty such Jacks.    And if I cannot, Ill find those that shall. Scurvy knave! I am none of his flirt-gills. I am none of his skains-mates.   [To PETER]   And thou must stand by, too, and suffer every knave to use me at his pleasure?
dialogs.translated: If he says anything against me, Ill teach him a lesson, even if he were tougher than he isand twenty wise-asses like him. And if I couldnt take him down myself, Ill find someone who can. That rotten scoundrel! Im not one of his flirty girls. Im not one of his low-life scheming friends.

dialogs.original: I saw no man use you at his pleasure. If I had, my weapon should quickly have been out, I warrant you.   I dare draw as soon as another man if I see occasion in a good quarrel and the law on my side.
dialogs.translated: I didnt see anybody use you for pleasure. If I had, Id have quickly pulled out my weapon, I assure you. I draw my sword as quickly as any other man if I see a good fight brewing and the law is on my side.

dialogs.original: Now, afore God, I am so vexed that every part about me quivers. Scurvy knave!   [To ROMEO]   Pray you, sir, a word.And as I told you, my young lady bid me inquire you out. What she bade me say, I will keep to myself.   But first let me tell ye, if ye should lead her into a fools paradise, as they say, it were a very gross kind of behavior, as they say.   For the gentlewoman is young, and therefore, if you should deal double with her, trulyit were an ill thing to be offered to any gentlewoman, and very weak dealing.
dialogs.translated: Now, by God, Im so upset that Im shaking. That rotten scoundrel!

dialogs.original: Nurse, commend me to thy lady and mistress. I protest unto thee
dialogs.translated: Nurse, speak well of me to your mistress. I pledge to you

dialogs.original: Good heart, and i faith, I will tell her as much. Lord, Lord, she will be a joyful woman.
dialogs.translated: Your heart is good, and I promise, I will tell her that. Lord, Lord, she will be a joyful woman.

dialogs.original: What wilt thou tell her, Nurse? Thou dost not mark me.
dialogs.translated: What are you going to tell her, Nurse? Youre not understanding me.

dialogs.original: I will tell her, sir, that you do protest, which, as I take it, is a gentlemanlike offer.
dialogs.translated: I will tell her, sir, that you protest to her, which I think is a gentlemanly offer.

dialogs.original: Bid her devise    Some means to come to shrift this afternoon.    And there she shall at Friar Lawrence cell    Be shrived and married.   [Gives her coins]   Here is for thy pains.
dialogs.translated: Tell her to devise a way to come to confession this afternoon. And there, at Friar Lawrences cell, she can make confession and we will be married. [Holding out some money to the NURSE] Here is a reward for your efforts.

dialogs.original: No, truly, sir. Not a penny.
dialogs.translated: No, truly, sir. I wont take your money.

dialogs.original: Go to. I say you shall.
dialogs.translated: Go on, I insist.

dialogs.original: [Takes the money]  This afternoon, sir? Well, she shall be there.
dialogs.translated: [Taking the money] This afternoon, sir? She will be there.

dialogs.original: And stay, good Nurse. Behind the abbey wall    Within this hour my man shall be with thee    And bring thee cords made like a tackled stair,    Which to the high top-gallant of my joy    Must be my convoy in the secret night.    Farewell. Be trusty, and Ill quit thy pains.    Farewell. Commend me to thy mistress.
dialogs.translated: Just a moment, good Nurse. In an hour, behind the abbey wall, one of my servants will meet you and give you a rope ladder. Ill then use the ladder to secretly climb up to Juliets room tonight. Farewell. Be worthy of my trust, and Ill repay you for your help. Farewell. Speak well of me to your mistress.

dialogs.original: Now God in heaven bless thee! Hark you, sir.
dialogs.translated: May God in heaven bless you! Now listen, sir.

dialogs.original: What sayst thou, my dear Nurse?
dialogs.translated: What, my dear Nurse?

dialogs.original: Is your man secret? Did you neer hear say,Two may keep counsel, putting one away?
dialogs.translated: Can your servant be trusted? Have you ever heard the saying, Two men may keep a secret, but only if one is far away?"

dialogs.original: Warrant thee, my mans as true as steel.
dialogs.translated: I guarantee you that my man is as trustworthy as steel.

dialogs.original: Well, sir, my mistress is the sweetest lady.Lord, Lord! when twas a little prating thing.Oh, there is a nobleman in town, one Paris, that would fain lay knife aboard,   but she, good soul, had as lief see a toad, a very toad, as see him. I anger her sometimes and tell her that Paris is the properer man.   But, Ill warrant you, when I say so, she looks as pale as any clout in the versal world. Doth not rosemary and Romeo begin bothwith a letter?
dialogs.translated: Well, sir, my mistress is the sweetest lady. Lord, Lord, when she was a little babyOh, there is one nobleman in the city, Paris, who would gladly lay claim to her. But Juliet, good soul that she is, would rather be with a toad, a toad, than him. Sometimes I make her angry by telling her that Paris is better looking than you. I swear to you, when I say that she turns as white as any sheet in the entire world. Dont rosemary and Romeo begin with the same letter?

dialogs.original: Ay, Nurse, what of that? Both with an R.
dialogs.translated: Yes, Nurse, what about that? Both begin with an  R.

dialogs.original: Ah, mocker, thats the dogs name. R is for theNo, I know it begins with some other letter, and she hath the prettiest sententious of it, of you and rosemary, that it would do you good to hear it.
dialogs.translated: Ah, you jokesterthats the dogs name. R is for theno, I know that word begins with another letter. She says such pretty things about you and rosemary that it would do you good to hear them.

dialogs.original: Commend me to thy lady.
dialogs.translated: Speak well of me to your lady.

dialogs.original: Ay, a thousand times Peter!
dialogs.translated: Yes, a thousand times. Peter!

dialogs.original: Anon!
dialogs.translated: Im ready.

dialogs.original: [Giving PETER her fan]  Before, and apace.
dialogs.translated: [Giving her fan to PETER] Go ahead of me, and go quickly.
